data.question: What method was used for the synthesis of lanthanide phosphonocarboxylate frameworks?
What technique was applied to prepare nanosheets from the bulk crystal samples of lanthanide phosphonocarboxylate frameworks?
What was the purpose of incorporating Y(III) ions into Eu(m-pbc) and Tb(m-pbc)?
data.answer: To enhance the emission intensities of the dimetallic compounds due to the dilution effect

data.question: How were the nanosheets of lanthanide phosphonocarboxylate frameworks characterized?
data.answer: The nanosheets were characterized by atomic force microscopy and transmission electron microscopy

data.question: What was the main advantage of using lanthanide phosphonocarboxylate frameworks for latent fingerprint imaging?
data.answer: The main advantage was the presence of free carboxylic groups that could react with fingerprint residues, benefiting efficient imaging for fingerprints on all kinds of material surfaces

data.question: What was the role of the m-pbc ligand in the photoluminescence studies of the lanthanide phosphonocarboxylate frameworks?
data.answer: The m-pbc ligand acted as an efficient antenna toward Eu and Tb(III) ions, facilitating efficient sensitization of lanthanide-ion luminescence

data.question: Why was the hydrothermal method chosen for the synthesis of lanthanide phosphonocarboxylate frameworks?
data.answer: The hydrothermal method was chosen because it allowed for the carboxyl groups to remain uncoordinated and act as functional sites for amino acid reactions, which is crucial for the intended application in latent fingerprint imaging

data.question: How does the incorporation of Y(III) ions affect the photoluminescence properties of Eu(m-pbc) and Tb(m-pbc)?
data.answer: The incorporation of Y(III) ions into Eu(m-pbc) and Tb(m-pbc) leads to enhanced emission intensities due to the dilution effect, demonstrating that Y(III) doping contributes positively to the photoluminescence properties

data.question: What is the significance of the sonication-assisted liquid-exfoliation method in the preparation of nanosheets from bulk crystals?
data.answer: The significance of the sonication-assisted liquid-exfoliation method lies in its effectiveness at inducing exfoliation of Ln(m-pbc)-NSs down to several layers, which is crucial for their application in latent fingerprint imaging due to the enhanced surface area and reactivity

data.question: How does the presence of free carboxylic groups in the lanthanide phosphonocarboxylate frameworks contribute to latent fingerprint imaging?
data.answer: The free carboxylic groups in the lanthanide phosphonocarboxylate frameworks react with amino groups in fingerprint residues to form covalent bonds, which benefits the strong labeling of fingerprints and enables efficient imaging on various material surfaces

data.question: Is the hydrothermal method essential for maintaining the uncoordinated state of carboxyl groups in the synthesis of lanthanide phosphonocarboxylate frameworks?
Can the sonication-assisted liquid-exfoliation method produce nanosheets with a thickness distribution down to a single layer?
Do the lanthanide phosphonocarboxylate frameworks exhibit photoluminescence properties without the m-pbc ligand acting as an antenna?
Is the incorporation of Y(III) ions into Eu(m-pbc) and Tb(m-pbc) detrimental to their photoluminescence properties?
Are the nanosheets of lanthanide phosphonocarboxylate frameworks only applicable for latent fingerprint imaging on smooth surfaces?
Does the reaction between active carboxylic groups and fingerprint residues hinder the labeling efficiency for latent fingerprint imaging?
Are the photoluminescence studies of lanthanide phosphonocarboxylate frameworks independent of the m-pbc ligand's role as an antenna?
